original_data.question: An investigator is studying traumatic knee joint injuries in college athletes. Images and tissue samples are collected from 4 athletes with cartilaginous injury and 4 athletes with bone fractures. After 8 weeks, the athletes with bone fractures show almost complete resolution, while the athletes with cartilaginous injuries show only minimal signs of healing. The investigator hypothesizes that this is due to the absence of progenitor cells for matrix regeneration. Transplant of which of the following tissues would most likely promote healing in the group with cartilaginous injury?

model_response:
The perichondrium is a connective tissue that covers cartilage in many locations in the body. It contains a population of progenitor cells that can differentiate into chondrocytes, and it is important for the repair of small cartilage defects. Mature chondrocytes are present in the matrix of cartilage, but they are not able to migrate and repopulate damaged cartilage. Osteoblasts are associated with bone, not cartilage. Proteoglycans are a major component of cartilage matrix, but they are not associated with a progenitor cell population.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Those individuals engaged in research.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Individuals' concept of their own bodies.
A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation.

A non-vascular form of connective tissue composed of CHONDROCYTES embedded in a matrix that includes CHONDROITIN SULFATE and various types of FIBRILLAR COLLAGEN. There are three major types: HYALINE CARTILAGE; FIBROCARTILAGE; and ELASTIC CARTILAGE.

Restoration of integrity to traumatized tissue.
Those individuals engaged in research.

Relatively undifferentiated cells that retain the ability to divide and proliferate throughout postnatal life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into specialized cells.
The physiological renewal, repair, or replacement of tissue.
Transference of a tissue or organ from either an alive or deceased donor, within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.

Collections of differentiated CELLS, such as EPITHELIUM; CONNECTIVE TISSUE; MUSCLES; and NERVE TISSUE. Tissues are cooperatively arranged to form organs with specialized functions such as RESPIRATION; DIGESTION; REPRODUCTION; MOVEMENT; and others.
Encouragement of the progress or growth or acceptance of something.
Restoration of integrity to traumatized tissue.
Any number of entities (members) considered as a unit.
